definitions.definition: to go down below the surface or towards the bottom of a liquid or soft substance

examples.text: The ship sank to the bottom of the sea.
The submarine sank after an explosion.
We're sinking!
The wheels started to sink into the mud.
The little boat sank beneath the waves.
It seemed as though the ship had sunk without trace.
Duane was in waist-deep and sinking fast.
He sank up to his knees in the mud.
Our feet sank deep into the soft sand as we walked.

definitions.definition: to damage a boat or ship so that it goes below the surface of the sea, etc.

examples.text: The battleship was sunk by a torpedo.
Bombs sank all four carriers.
Five brothers all died when their ship was sunk.

definitions.definition: to move downwards, especially by falling or sitting down

examples.text: I sank into an armchair.
She **sank back** into her seat, exhausted.
The old man had **sunk to his knees**.
He sank lower into his chair.
I sank gratefully into the warm, dry bed.
She sank gracefully down onto a cushion at his feet.
She sank to the ground, exhausted.
The sun was sinking in the west.
The sun had sunk below the horizon.
The foundations of the building are starting to sink.

definitions.definition: to decrease in amount, volume, strength, etc.

examples.text: The pound has sunk to its lowest recorded level against the dollar.
He is clearly sinking fast *(= getting weaker quickly and will soon die)*.
The project gradually sank into oblivion.
The airline industry is sinking under the weight of its losses.
Her voice sank to a whisper.

definitions.definition: to make a deep hole in the ground

examples.text: to **sink a well/shaft/mine**

definitions.definition: to place something in the ground by digging

examples.text: to sink a post into the ground

definitions.definition: to prevent somebody or somebody’s plans from succeeding

examples.text: I think I've just sunk my chances of getting the job.
If the car breaks down, we'll **be sunk** *(= have serious problems)*.

definitions.definition: to hit a ball into a hole in golf or snooker

examples.text: He sank a 12-foot putt to win the match.

definitions.definition: to drink something quickly, especially a large amount of alcohol

examples.text: They sank three pints each in 10 minutes.

definitions.definition: to be in a state of unhappiness or deep thought

examples.text: She just sat there, sunk in thought.

definitions.definition: used to talk about people who leave an organization, a company, etc. that is having difficulties, without caring about the people who are left
used to say that somebody suddenly feels sad or depressed about something

examples.text: My heart sank when I saw how much work there was left.
She watched him go **with a sinking heart**.

definitions.definition: to agree to forget about your disagreements

examples.text: We need to sink our differences and present a united opposition to the plan.

definitions.definition: an unpleasant feeling that you get when you realize that something bad has happened or is going to happen

examples.text: I had a horrible sinking feeling when I saw the ambulance outside the house.

definitions.definition: to be in a situation where you will either succeed by your own efforts or fail completely

examples.text: The new students were just left to sink or swim.
In a situation like this, you either sink or swim.

definitions.definition: to have such low moral standards that you do something very bad

examples.text: Stealing from your friends? How could you sink so low?
I can't believe that anyone would sink to such depths.
With this article the newspaper has sunk to a new low.

definitions.definition: to behave in a worse way than ever before

examples.text: The government has stooped to an all-time low with this policy.
Reality TV has sunk to new lows.

wordOrigin: verb Old English sincan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zinken and German sinken.
